name: Japanese Roasted Kabocha Squash
description: Looking for a quick and delicious way to enjoy kabocha squash? Try this Japanese-style Roasted Kabocha Squash that‚Äòs thinly sliced and oven-baked until slightly charred and fork-tender. Here, I show you how to lightly flavor it two ways: with a shichimi togarashi spice blend and sweetened soy sauce. These classic Japanese seasonings both enhance the natural sweetness and beautiful flavor of the kabocha.

video.name: Perfect Fall Dish: How to Make Japanese Roasted Kabocha Squash
video.description:
Looking for a quick and delicious way to enjoy kabocha squash? Try this Japanese-style Roasted Kabocha Squash that‚Äôs thinly sliced and oven-baked until slightly charred and fork-tender. Here, I show you how to lightly flavor it two ways: with shichimi togarashi spice blend and with sweetened soy sauce. These classic Japanese seasonings both enhance the natural sweetness and beautiful flavor of the kabocha.
RECIPE: https://www.justonecookbook.com/japanese-roasted-kabocha-squash/

INGREDIENTS
1¬æ lb (794 g) kabocha squash (about a quarter of a large kabocha; 1¬Ω lb or 680 g after discarding the seeds)
2 Tbsp neutral-flavored oil (vegetable, rice bran, canola, etc.) (or extra virgin olive oil)
¬Ω-¬æ tsp kosher salt (Diamond Crystal; use half for table salt)
¬º tsp freshly ground black pepper

For the Shichimi Flavor
¬Ω tsp shichimi togarashi (Japanese seven spice)

For the Sweetened Soy Sauce Flavor
2 tsp soy sauce (use GF soy sauce for gluten free)
¬Ω tsp sugar

Japanese knife: Kikuichi (https://kikuichi.net/)

CHAPTERS
0:00 - Remove Squash Seeds
0:08 - Cut thinly and season
0:28 - Divide into Two Batches: Soy Sauce Flavor
0:37 - Divide into Two Batches: Spicy Shichimi Flavor
0:44 - Place on Baking Sheet & in Oven
0:50 - Flip after 10 mins
1:05 - Ready to eat Kabocha Squash

#kabocha #squashrecipe #japanesefood 

Let's cook EASY + AUTHENTIC Japanese recipes at home!
Konnichiwa! I'm Nami, the creator of the Just One Cookbook website and cooking blog. I am glad that you are here with me. Here and on JustOneCookbook.com, you can find over 1,200 recipes, cooking tips, step-by-step instructions, ingredients, and shopping guides focused on Japanese cuisine.

I'm a native Japanese, born and raised in Yokohama, Japan, and now live in San Francisco, California, with my husband Mr. JOC, two high school kids, and a dog named Miso. I also wrote three Japanese cookbooks, where I share popular recipes like Oyakodon, Tamagoyaki, Chawanmushi, Sushi, Okonomiyaki, Mochi Ice Cream, Gyoza, Ramen, and more!

recipeIngredient: 2 Tbsp neutral oil ((or extra virgin olive oil))
¬Ω tsp shichimi togarashi (Japanese seven spice) ((gives a spicy kick))
2 tsp soy sauce ((use GF soy sauce for gluten free))

recipeInstructions.text: Gather all the ingredients. Set two oven racks at the upper top and lower middle positions. Preheat the oven to 450¬∫F (230¬∫C). For a convection oven, reduce the cooking temperature by 25¬∫F (15¬∫C).
recipeInstructions.name: Gather all the ingredients. Set two oven racks at the upper top and lower middle positions. Preheat the oven to 450¬∫F (230¬∫C). For a convection oven, reduce the cooking temperature by 25¬∫F (15¬∫C).

itemListElement.text: Using a spoon, scrape out and discard the seeds from 1¬æ lb kabocha squash. The kabocha skin is edible and nutritious, so rinse and pat it dry with a paper towel.
itemListElement.name: Using a spoon, scrape out and discard the seeds from 1¬æ lb kabocha squash. The kabocha skin is edible and nutritious, so rinse and pat it dry with a paper towel.

itemListElement.text: Cut the kabocha in half widthwise, cutting through the middle of the U-shaped piece. Cut off the stem end, if any. Tip: When the kabocha pieces are shorter, the knife can slice through more easily.
itemListElement.name: Cut the kabocha in half widthwise, cutting through the middle of the U-shaped piece. Cut off the stem end, if any. Tip: When the kabocha pieces are shorter, the knife can slice through more easily.

itemListElement.text: Slice the kabocha thinly, about ‚Öõ to ‚Öï inch (3‚Äì5 mm) thick.
itemListElement.name: Slice the kabocha thinly, about ‚Öõ to ‚Öï inch (3‚Äì5 mm) thick.

itemListElement.text: Transfer the kabocha slices to a large bowl. Add 2 Tbsp neutral oil, ¬Ω‚Äì¬æ tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt, and ¬º tsp freshly ground black pepper.
itemListElement.name: Transfer the kabocha slices to a large bowl. Add 2 Tbsp neutral oil, ¬Ω‚Äì¬æ tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt, and ¬º tsp freshly ground black pepper.

itemListElement.text: Using your hands (or a spoon), toss the kabocha with the oil and seasonings to coat well. Then, transfer half of the slices to another bowl.
itemListElement.name: Using your hands (or a spoon), toss the kabocha with the oil and seasonings to coat well. Then, transfer half of the slices to another bowl.

itemListElement.text: Sprinkle ¬Ω tsp shichimi togarashi (Japanese seven spice) over the kabocha slices in one bowl and toss to coat.
itemListElement.name: Sprinkle ¬Ω tsp shichimi togarashi (Japanese seven spice) over the kabocha slices in one bowl and toss to coat.

recipeInstructions.name: To Add the Sweetened Soy Sauce

itemListElement.text: Add 2 tsp soy sauce and ¬Ω tsp sugar to the kabocha slices in the other bowl and toss everything well.
itemListElement.name: Add 2 tsp soy sauce and ¬Ω tsp sugar to the kabocha slices in the other bowl and toss everything well.

itemListElement.text: Prepare two baking sheets lined with parchment paper. Place the shichimi-flavored kabocha slices in a single layer on one baking sheet and the soy sauce-flavored kabocha on the other. Don‚Äòt crowd the baking sheets. Tip: If you‚Äòd like a deeper char on the kabocha slices, do not use the parchment paper and bake directly on the baking sheet. This way, you can safely broil the kabocha slices longer without worrying about any paper catching on fire.
itemListElement.name: Prepare two baking sheets lined with parchment paper. Place the shichimi-flavored kabocha slices in a single layer on one baking sheet and the soy sauce-flavored kabocha on the other. Don‚Äòt crowd the baking sheets. Tip: If you‚Äòd like a deeper char on the kabocha slices, do not use the parchment paper and bake directly on the baking sheet. This way, you can safely broil the kabocha slices longer without worrying about any paper catching on fire.

itemListElement.text: Place the baking sheets in the oven on the upper and lower racks (you‚Äòll switch their positions later). Bake at 450¬∫F (230¬∫C) for 10 minutes. Then, take out the two baking sheets.
itemListElement.name: Place the baking sheets in the oven on the upper and lower racks (you‚Äòll switch their positions later). Bake at 450¬∫F (230¬∫C) for 10 minutes. Then, take out the two baking sheets.

itemListElement.text: Using tongs, flip the kabocha slices. Put the baking sheets back into the oven, rotating the directions of the pans and switching their positions on the upper and lower racks for even baking. Bake for an additional 5 minutes or until the kabocha is fork-tender. If you cut the slices thicker than I did, it may take slightly longer to cook. Next, switch to the Broil setting and broil high for 2‚Äì3 minutes until slightly charred. Tip: Make sure the upper rack is at least 4 inches away from the heating element so your parchment paper doesn‚Äòt catch on fire. Watch it closely.
itemListElement.name: Using tongs, flip the kabocha slices. Put the baking sheets back into the oven, rotating the directions of the pans and switching their positions on the upper and lower racks for even baking. Bake for an additional 5 minutes or until the kabocha is fork-tender. If you cut the slices thicker than I did, it may take slightly longer to cook. Next, switch to the Broil setting and broil high for 2‚Äì3 minutes until slightly charred. Tip: Make sure the upper rack is at least 4 inches away from the heating element so your parchment paper doesn‚Äòt catch on fire. Watch it closely.

itemListElement.text: Remove the upper baking sheet from the oven. Next, move the lower baking sheet to the upper rack and broil high for 2 minutes.
itemListElement.name: Remove the upper baking sheet from the oven. Next, move the lower baking sheet to the upper rack and broil high for 2 minutes.

itemListElement.text: Let the first baking sheet cool on a wire rack. After 2 minutes, take out the second baking sheet and let it cool on a wire rack.
itemListElement.name: Let the first baking sheet cool on a wire rack. After 2 minutes, take out the second baking sheet and let it cool on a wire rack.

itemListElement.text: Transfer the Japanese Roasted Kabocha Squash to two plates and enjoy!
itemListElement.name: Transfer the Japanese Roasted Kabocha Squash to two plates and enjoy!

itemListElement.text: You can keep the leftovers in an airtight container and keep them for 3 days in the refrigerator or for up to a month in the freezer.
itemListElement.name: You can keep the leftovers in an airtight container and keep them for 3 days in the refrigerator or for up to a month in the freezer.

review.reviewBody: I owe you so much for introducing me to kabocha squash! It is so good. It has replaced bitternut as my favorite. Now I'm going to the Asian Food Market to look for the Shichimi Togarashi. It sounds intriging. Also, do you cook with pea vines or pea shoots? I'd be interested to see what you do with those. Thank You Namiko!
